awd_titl_txt: AMPS: Model Reduction for Analysis, Identification, and Optimal Design of Power Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Power networks are a rich source of dynamical systems that play a critical role in the infrastructure of modern society. Costly computer simulations are needed to model the impact of virtually any planning, monitoring, control and stability analysis task of the power grid, due to its scale and complexity. Such simulations become only more complicated with the growth of renewable energy generation such as solar and wind. To expedite dynamic simulation and to aid the design and optimization of power grids, this project pursues a suite of new model reduction algorithms tailored to the special considerations of power network modeling. The proposed methods will take advantage of the large volume of observation data that is available, moving toward algorithms for reliably estimating the state of the grid. This project supports 2 graduate students each year of the 3 year project.

This project will develop and analyze new approaches to model reduction that are specially adapted to the needs of power grid operation and analysis. The project will pursue both projection-based methods and data-driven algorithms, considering nonlinear power network equations and their linearization. The resulting methods seek reliable, high-fidelity, low-order models that preserve critical physics-based structural features and parametric dependence germane to power grid dynamics. Data-driven modeling frameworks will be refined to allow for rapid model updating using near real-time observation streams from phasor measurement units. Reduced models will also contribute to the development of cost-effective power grid optimization tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

por.por_cntn:
Power networks are  interconnected dynamical systems that form a vital core for the infrastructure of modern society. Modeling the impacts of planning, monitoring, control, and stability analysis on these complex systems necessitates costly computer simulations, a need that has only intensified with the integration of renewable energy resources like solar and wind. Seeking to respond to this challenge, this project has advanced the development of novel model reduction algorithms that are tailored to meeting operational and analytical needs of electric power systems. These methods leverage the abundantly available phasor measurement data, paving the way for algorithms capable of accurately estimating the grid state.

The research accomplished encompasses several diverse areas: the application of Gaussian Process modeling to power system dynamics, refinement of Mixed-Integer Linear Programming for optimal network design, adaptation of the Discrete Empirical Interpolation Method for anomaly detection, and innovations in the detection of forced oscillations in power systems with minimal data reliance.  Additionally, project activities introduced structured barycentric model representations for engineering applications and developed data-driven techniques for pinpointing oscillatory sources in power systems through impulse responses. Optimal model reduction techniques that take advantage of and retain the structure of (linear and nonlinear) power network dynamics were developed. Moreover, model reduction approaches for approximating parametrically varying power network models were introduced. Computational strategies for analyzing time-periodic systems with modally truncated Floquet transformations, alongside a variant of the dominant pole algorithm, were also a focus. A novel framework for modeling dissipative dynamics was developed, improving both system identification and approximation through the empirical derivation of supply rates.


Last Modified: 04/11/2024
Modified by: Serkan Gugercin
